description: American English, of disputed origin, but first attested in the mid-19th century as a verb. The earliest example is capitalized, so it is likely a nickname of the proper name Joshua (see more there). Perhaps it was taken as a typical name of an old farmer.

verbs.description: josh (third-person singular simple present joshes, present participle joshing, simple past and past participle joshed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To tease someone in a kindly or friendly fashion.
(intransitive) To make or exchange good-natured jokes.
